Dental Work - High blood sugar?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎12-15-2009 03:12 PM

Last week I got 5 cavities filled........ the dentist told me i would be experiencing hot/cold sensitivity... well - this has definitely been the case to the point of needing to take an OTC painkiller to relieve it. Not a big deal. However, my blood sugar has been running about 150-180................ no matter what I do!! I have increased my basal rate and changed my bolus ratios and NO EFFECT.

Anyone else had this problem after dental work?? (like FIVE days after getting cavities filled?)

Thanks for the insight...

‎12-15-2009 03:46 PM

I have had trouble in the past but can�t say it went on for 5 days though. I do remember reading an article once how dental work can stir up germs that normally sit dormant and can cause problems for some people more than others. I always thought I was one of those people that had more problems than others. It is possible you may be sensitive to that also and having 5 cavities filled really stirred stuff up.
.

Kelly
www.kellywpa.wordpress.com
Type 1, Diagnosed January, 1984
Dexcom Seven Plus CGMS

Pumping With Animas PIng & Apidra Since June, 2010

‎12-16-2009 04:30 PM

I have been having major dental work and have found the opposite problem. I am on a pump and have maintained very well during the work--often for several hours. Later that day or at night, my BG would crash. I even got sick one night with a low--cranberry juice really make a mess, if you get sick. So, highs have not been aproblem for me!

‎12-16-2009 05:05 PM

I haven't had major dental work since diagnosis, but if I go for a cleaning, my numbers run high.. stess + pain/discomfort = high blood sugar


You go to school to learn, not for a report card.
You use your meter to learn, not for a report card

Type 1 (LADA).. Novolog/Levemir

Adult onset T1

‎12-17-2009 06:22 AM

Well, did he have you take a amoxicillan about 1 hr before going in? This Reduces the chance of Infections, which we are very suspectable too..

If oyu're still having problems 5 days after? Best call him or see another Dentist, experience with dealing with Insulin Diabetics.. many won't take them BTW.

and Filling 5 at a time sound like alot for just one day...

and see a Dental Hygentist every 6mos is not a bad idea either..

Our teeth are one of those "complications" we get and loose them

DennisIDDM@aol.com
